dotech welcome to another episode uh my name is Helen Scott and today I'm going
to be interviewing Anna skari so Anna is a creative she uses her communication
and her storytelling and she's used it to tell git in a simple way so Anna
welcome thanks for having me Helen I'm excited I'm excited too I'm I'm GNA see
how many stories of my G frustration I can weave into this interview um so uh
Anice published her first book learning git it's on the airay platform you published it June last year Anna yes
June last year um June last year so um I've got a copy
of the book I've been very efficient and put it back on my bookshelf over here I will get out
um but Anna for the purposes of this interview let's start let's start right at the beginning um tell us a little bit
more about you and what you enjoyed doing before we get started into the book I think what I enjoyed doing is
taking a complicated topic or a topic that confuses people and making it
simpler and more approachable and presenting the information in a way that it's easier to learn for beginners um so
that's what I did with Git and um and that's what I also do in my day job because I work as a technical writer so
in my day job I also take various topics and explain them in a simpler way and present information in a simple way so
that people can consume it better fantastic and that's so important
you know having a technic writing background myself as well that's it's just super important that when a user
comes you know looks for the documentation that it is written in such a way that you can actually help them to
move forward and get past the problem that's made them go and look at documentation in the first place right
yeah okay so uh I'm going to not derail this interview completely with how annoyed I can get a g sometimes but I
think maybe some of our audience might share some of those frustrations
um what what was your primary motivated behind writing this
book okay so the reason I wrote this book is because I needed this book so
I'm just going to backtrack a little and say that my entryway into the world of tech was through the world of ux design
so user experience design um so at some point in my life I did a ux design boot
camp and I worked as a ux designer and then uh when I was working as a ux
designer I'd realized that I knew how to design apps and websites so sort of like
an architect but I didn't know how to actually build those apps and websites I wasn't like the construction company
that gets the the blueprints and actually build them and I got really curious about how these things are built
so I ended up doing a coding boot camp um and that's kind of a three to four
month intensive program learned the basics of web development and then worked as a front-end developer and the
first time that I got introduced to G was in that coding boot camp um but it was one hour where they just kind of
told us get add get commit get push go off you go and obviously that may
have been sort of enough when you were just working on your own on your projects in the coding boot camp but
once I got my first job as a junior front-end developer and I had to work with a team of developers and Senior
developers um I was terrified of G I mean every time I had to do something that I deemed was complicated which was
almost everything um I would call on the senior developers and ask them to help me and I was always worried I was about
to destroy the repository and take down the entire platform and the entire website um and this was like a massive
e-commerce platform so that that would have not been good um little did I know
that that was not the case and that that was not never going to happen but um anyways so at some point during that job
I realized I want to conquer this fear I want to learn how to use GID and I want to understand how it works so that I can
be an independent uh developer and um not have
to ask for help all the time so I started learning uh you know looking for online resources to learn git and what I
realized was that there weren't really any online resources that were designed for people like me that were really new
to Tech um that had transitioned into Tech from non-technical backgrounds and
that explained things in a simple way and then at some point this creative idea came to me of how I could teach git
using colors and storytelling and visuals um and I mean this was after i'
kind of understood some of the basics so the first thing that I did was actually make an online course um teaching git um
and that's still available online at the moment it's on udemy who knows where it will be in the future but that um that
journey I thought that the when I was making the online course I still wanted to write a book but I thought that the
barrier to entry to write the book was higher than to make an online course was with online courses you just kind of
record your voice make some slides record them um so I could do that a lot easier and publish it online a lot
easier but once I released that online course I started getting reviews I started getting feedback and I realized
my way of teaching get really resonated with a lot of people um there were a lot of people that just like me had not been
served by the git teaching resources out there up until now and my approach to
organizing information and presenting Concepts worked for them and then I was like all right since it works let's
write this book um I am also a writer in my personal time and I I love to journal
so writing is my medium of choice um and so yeah that's kind of how this book
came about this is the book that I wish I had had in my first week of that coding boot camp um or especially in
that first week of my new job as a front-end developer 100% And just in hearing that
story there's so much that resonated with me um and you know people that I've talked about regardless of how you end
up in the profession whether you you're coming through a degree you're coming through a boot camp your S taught
whatever it is how much you learn about Version Control and you know get as part
of that is really variable in my experience sometimes it's purely conceptual like there is this thing that
you can do you will learn about it on your job and then you turn up at your job and you're like oh I'm terrified I'm
going to delete the whole repository um so I think we've all been there and I think we've all had experience of
knowing who or even being at times that expert in git on the team that people go
to when they've they've gone beyond the the gpol will you know get update get
pushed they've gone beyond the basics and they're like oh I'm in trouble now something's not working um so I think
certainly I identified with a lot of what you said there and I expect our audience did as well so yeah the other
thing that actually have been very surprising is um that it's not just
developers that use git there are so many other people that work with developers or that do other jobs that
use git so and and this I've discovered since publishing the book um game artists mechanical engineers
also use git um sometimes ux designers have to collaborate with devs and share
assets or whatever even product managers so and and actually one of the most um
one of the biggest audiences my book uh actually got was technical writers because they often have this thing that
we call docs as code approach and they use git to manage the repositories for the documentation websites so um many
many some technical writers are come from a technical background but some don't and so technical Concepts don't
come naturally to them and yeah so my book has really served various different
audiences including Junior developers and experienced developers but also just so many other professions um which yeah
has been very eye openening yeah and again identified with it there because it was back in my technical writing
career and I started using git and I needed that g expert in the team that
developer and I was like I've got it I've got it in a mess please help me um
so let's let's move swiftly on to talking about the book itself which is why why majority of the audience will be
here um can you give us an overview of the book and talk about its structure a little bit more yes yeah yeah definitely
so the book is for absolute complete beginners um if you have a bit of experience you can maybe try to skip a
chapter normally you should do it from the beginning to the end though because it's a Hands-On learning experience um
where you're working on a specific repository throughout the entire book which is actually called the rainbow
repository um because you're listing the colors of the rainbow I'll explain that
a little bit more later but the first chapter actually just starts off with installing git and an introduction to
the command line because some people actually haven't worked in the command line and aren't familiar with it so it
really is a book for absolute beginners um and then I build this thing that I called the git diagram which is my way
of creating a mental model of the different areas of git and how they fit together so uh you have your project
directory the working directory the local repository and then inside the local repository you have the staging
area and the commit history and in when I was learning GID I came across diagrams that tried to kind of depict
these different areas and how they interact and they didn't really make sense to me so I've actually created my
own representation of these areas and this is really key to my teaching methodology because um the main part of
my teaching method methodology is creating a mental model of how things work and making things tangible so we
build the git diagram and once we have that we go over the process of making a commit um we introduce branches and what
they are and we create visualizations for all of these things so I visualize what branches look like they're just
pointers to commits um then what else I have a list here uh I go over merging
and I introduce uh the two types of merges fast forward merges three-way merges uh this is but we're at chapter
five now um and there we just go over the experience of doing a fastforward
merge not yet a three-way merge that's a bit more spicy and it comes later on in the Learning Journey um and then in
chapter six is when we actually go from working just in the local repository just on your computer on your own and we
introduce hosting services so GitHub gitlab bitbucket um and uh and remote repositories
basically so one thing I should mention right now just a quick parenthesis is that the book is not prescriptive so you
can use whichever hosting service you want you can use whichever text editor you want I didn't want
to um exclude anyone that uses maybe a different technology and I wanted to
make the book accessible to yeah anything so um yeah that closing pareses
now moving on uh chapter 7 we jump into um creating uh and pushing to a remote
repository so we're really into you know local repository remote repository chapter eight we go over cloning um and
fetching data so in chapter eight is where the learning experience we
simulate that you're working with another person so in the book we say that a friend of yours wants to join you
on your rainbow project so they create a loc uh well they clone your remote
repository and they create a local reposit repository called friend rainbow and I mean if you have a friend that you
can actually do all the exercises with then that's ideal um but the most realistic thing is that you just create
a second local repository on your computer and you just kind of pretend it's on someone else's computer um but
this is really important because at the end of the day git is a collaboration tool right it's it's Version Control and
collaboration so if you don't have any representations of how the collaboration happens then that leaves out basically
more than half of git um so so yeah so chapter eight you're learning how to clone how to fetch data from a repe
remote repos story and chapter nine finally we get into the spicy topic of well not that spicy three-way merges are
pretty simple but then chapter 10 we get into merge conflicts which is the spicier topic and the thing that a lot
of people are afraid of um chapter 11 rebasing rebasing I'd say is the most
advanced thing that I cover in my book um like I said this book is a real
Basics and beginner book so rebasing is yeah at the at the end and finally the
last chapter is pull requests or merge requests whatever terminology you want to use and obviously pull requests merge
requests they're not actually a feature of git itself they're a feature of the hosting Services um um so GitHub git
laab bit bucket and others there are others I'm just not going to start naming 20 different hosting Services um
but I thought that they were so important um because they really yeah they they're essential almost for
everyone's workflow so I thought okay I'll make an exception and include them even though this is a book about git um
and yeah that's kind of an overview and like I mentioned you're working on this
rainbow project and it's Hands-On um you are with your computer doing the exercises so you are supposed to do the

but I have created an appendix where I've offered instructions on how someone
can start like create the minimum setup for their project to start off on any chapter because yeah maybe you read the

way to that chapter just to be able to review it um but yeah that's that's a kind of overview of of the book

when I uh when I ask this next question so for example you've made extensive use
of color in this book and you mentioned the rainbow project repeatedly um what made you choose that
theme and why yeah so so when my
creative idea of how I could teach git in a simple way came to me it was all about using color because I thought to
myself um one of the really confusing or or yeah difficult things with Git when
you're teaching it is that there's commit hashes so every commit a commit is a version of your project every
commit has a commit hash so 40 characters letters and numbers that's unique and it's like a name for the
commit but if you're teaching it and you're having to refer to well remember commit 69 Zed blah blah blah blah blah
that is so confusing and I mean who wants to learn like that so I thought to
myself how could I use color instead and so let me give an example in the rainbow
project the very first thing you add to your project you create a rainbow. txt file so a text file very simple I keep
everything really simple and I'll make a comment about that in a second um and the first thing you add is just red is
the first color of the rainbow you just add that sentence first line of your file and you add that to the staging
area and you make a commit and then I represent that commit in the diagrams as a circle that is red and so from then on
I can just say the red commit and that just simplifies the learning experience
it makes it a lot more memorable and and also very much more visual because I'm not having to include like a little
commit hash in my diagram to try to refer to the commit um and yeah that's
why I I use color in my teaching methodology and the other really important and and the rainbow was just a
really nice way to structure it you know we all well many of us most of us know the the order of the colors of the
rainbow so it's a very familiar thing and it was easy to then yeah structure
the whole book that way although at the end I ran out of colors and I just had to add some random colors I actually
have at the end you add another file to your project called otherc colors. txt and you start adding like pink is not a
color in the rainbow and gray is not a color in the rainbow cuz I literally ran out of colors but also because I wanted
to show you know how you add new files to your project but the the other thing I want to say about keeping things
simple is that um one of the decisions I made with this book is that it would
have no code in it so the files in your project are just txt files which are
just really plain text files they're not even markdown files like it is so simple
because I thought if I include if I make the project that you work on in the book a web development project or data
science project a a Java project a python project anything it will exclude
some people for whom that is not familiar and and let's say yeah fine
well those people can go and look it up it just complicates things it's not necessary um I wanted someone to just be

other Tech Concepts which are not relevant to just learning git so yeah
that's kind of that was my my way of approaching yeah how to how to teach
